answers: display() is called before it is defined

questions.question: Point out the error in the following program.
Which of the following is correct about err used in the declaration given below?
questions.program: typedef enum error { warning, test, exception } err;
options: It is a typedef for enum error.
It is a variable of type enum error.
answers: It is a typedef for enum error.
questions.answerDescription: A typedef gives a new name to an existing data type. So err is a new name for enum error.

questions.question: Point out the error in the following program.
Which of the declaration is correct?
questions.answerDescription: int length; denotes that variable length is int(integer) data type. char int; here int is a keyword cannot be used a variable name. int long; here long is a keyword cannot be used a variable name. float double; here double is a keyword cannot be used a variable name. So, the answer is int length;(Option A).

questions.question: Which of the following operations are INCORRECT?
questions.answerDescription: float a = 3.14; a = a%3; gives "Illegal use of floating point" error. The modulus (%) operator can only be used on integer types. We have to use fmod() function in math.h for float values.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly represents a long double constant?
questions.answerDescription: 6.68 is double. 6.68L is long double constant. 6.68f is float constant. 6.68LF is not allowed in c.

questions.question: Which of the structure is incorrcet?
questions.answerDescription: Option B gives "Undefined structure in 'aa'" error.

questions.question: Which of the structure is correct?
questions.answerDescription: In 2 and 3 semicolon are missing in structure element.

typedef long a; extern int a c; while compiling this statement becomes extern int long c;. This will result in to "Declaration syntax error". typedef long a; extern a int c; while compiling this statement becomes extern long int c;. This will result in to "Too many types in declaration error". typedef long a; extern a c; while compiling this statement becomes extern long c;. This is a valid c declaration statement. It says variable c is long data type and defined in some other file or module. So, Option C is the correct answer.
